0.text:
Last night in Brussels I set out Britain’s
new settlement with the European Union.

6.text:
This morning I have just chaired a meeting
of the Cabinet in which I updated them on

10.text: the special status we have secured for Britain.

14.text:
And the Cabinet agreed that the government’s
position will be to recommend that Britain

19.text: remains in a reformed European Union.

23.text:
Now I want to speak directly to the British
people to explain why.

28.text:
We are approaching one of the biggest decisions
this country will face in our lifetimes.

33.text:
Whether to remain in a reformed European Union
– or to leave.

38.text:
This choice goes to the heart of the kind
of country we want to be. And the future that

46.text:
This is about how we trade with neighbouring
countries to create jobs, prosperity and financial

54.text:
And it is about how we co-operate to keep
our people safe and our country strong. I

62.text:
know there will be many passionate arguments
over the months ahead.

66.text:
And individual Cabinet Ministers will have
the freedom to campaign in a personal capacity

73.text:
But my responsibility as Prime Minister is
to speak plainly about what I believe is right

78.text:
for our country. I do not love Brussels. I
love Britain.

84.text:
I am the first to say that there are still
many ways in which Europe needs to improve

88.text:
– and that the task of reforming Europe
does not end with yesterday’s agreement.

95.text:
And I will never say that our country couldn’t
survive outside Europe.

99.text:
We are Great Britain – we can achieve great
things.

103.text: That is not the question in this referendum.

106.text:
The question is will we be safer, stronger
and better off working together in a reformed

113.text:
Europe or out on our own. I believe we will
be safer in a reformed Europe, because we

119.text:
can work with our European partners to fight
cross border crime and terrorism.

125.text:
I believe Britain will be stronger in a reformed
Europe because we can play a leading role

130.text:
in one of the world’s largest organisations
from within, helping to make the big decisions

136.text: on trade and security that determine our future.

141.text:
And I believe we will be better off in a reformed
Europe because British businesses will have

146.text:
full access to the free trade single market,
bringing jobs, investment and lower prices.

153.text:
Let me be clear. Leaving Europe would threaten
our economic and our national security.

162.text:
Those who want to leave Europe cannot tell
you if British businesses would be able to

166.text:
access Europe’s free trade single market
or if working people’s jobs are safe or

175.text:
All they are offering is risk at a time of
uncertainty - a leap in the dark.

181.text:
Our plan for Europe gives us the best of both
worlds.

185.text:
It underlines our special status through which
families across Britain get all the benefits

191.text:
of being in the EU, including more jobs, lower
prices and greater security.

198.text:
But our special status also means we are out
of the parts of Europe that don’t work for

204.text:
So we will never join the Euro, we will never
be part of Eurozone bailouts, never be part

211.text:
of the passport-free no borders area, or a
European Army or an EU super-state.

218.text:
Three years ago I committed to the British
people that I would renegotiate our position

223.text: in the European Union and hold an in-out referendum.

227.text: Now I am delivering that commitment.

232.text:
And whatever your decision, I will do my best
to deliver it.

238.text:
On Monday I will commence the process set
out under our Referendum Act.

242.text:
And I will go to parliament and propose that
the British people decide our future in Europe

249.text:
through an in-out referendum on Thursday 23rd
June.

254.text: The choice is in your hands.

260.text:
I believe that Britain will be safer, stronger
and better off in a reformed European Union.
